awd_titl_txt: REU site: Research in Physics & Astronomy at Louisiana State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics & Astronomy at Louisiana State University. The impact of this program is fostering interest in careers in science by introducing students to the nature of research-oriented careers in physics and astronomy and by developing research-related skills and knowledge. REU students are recruited nationally; students can be of any academic year and need not have a declared major, but must have completed the general physics sequence at their school. For the ten-week program, the participants are matched with faculty mentors based on student interests. Students join their mentors in active research projects, such as: 
i) performing analysis on data from the long baseline neutrino oscillation experiment T2K,
ii) instrumentation development and data simulations to support gravitational wave research, and
iii) designing quantum error correction codes and quantum memory for photonic qubits.

Weekly seminars and workshops introduce the students to faculty research, to skills development, to common research resources, and to professional development topics such as ethics and patents/intellectual property. Students participate in field trips and other activities, some of which are coordinated with concurrent LSU summer science programs in computer science, biomedical science and other areas. Students from all programs are lodged in proximity at on-campus apartment-style housing, to foster group interactions and a sense of community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal for this program is to foster interest in careers in science by introducing students to the nature of research-oriented careers and developing research-related skills and knowledge. This is accomplished by giving them a vibrant experience at a large research university. Participating in contemporary active research projects benefits the students' knowledge and helps them develop cognitive, analytic, and technical skills that will be valuable to them in future careers. The large diverse faculty of our department provides a wide spectrum of research topics and mentorship to our participants. The students obtain a broad-based view of physics and astronomy research, helping them refine their particular interests. At the same time, our department and the faculty mentors benefit from their productivity, from the inherent "advertising" and increased awareness by the students? home institutions of our departmental research and education programs.

Under this award we ran our program three times: Summer 2019, 2020, and 2021. Due to COVID-19, Summer 2020 was fully virtual, and Summer 2021 was hybrid with both virtual and in-person participants. For 2019 through 2021, we had 46 unique participants with 30 supported directly by the REU grant. Others were supported by individual faculty from other funds; 5 of these were high school students.

The majority of the participants' time was spent performing research with mentors, supplemented by science seminars, weekly group meetings, and professional development activities. A weekly science seminar series was held (in-person or virtual). The speakers were departmental faculty who talked about their research areas, providing the participants with an introduction to a variety of research topics. Additional professional development training was provided in conjunction with the other STEM summer programs and virtually with other REU programs and the American Physical Society.

We normally hold two science field trips. These highlight two local research facilities. LIGO-Livingston is one of the Laser Interferometry Gravitational-wave Observatory sites. CAMD is LSU's synchrotron research facility. We did our best to keep this tradition alive with virtual tours during the pandemic. As an introductory activity we also took students on a swamp tour early in the program when possible.

Each summer program ended with presentation of a poster or talk on the participant's research on the last day of the program. In 2019 this was a coordinated poster session across LSU's summer STEM programs with 77 student participants. For 2020 and 2021, students gave online oral presentations on their research to the department.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The REU participants worked in most research areas within our department: astronomy & astrophysics, cosmic-ray physics, high-energy physics, LIGO, loop quantum gravity and numerical relativity, nuclear physics, quantum science, condensed matter physics, and medical physics. All REU students prepared and presented posters or talks for presentation at the end of each summer. Students who made posters were able to take them for display at their home institutions. Several participants have first or co-authored publications published, with some still in preparation. Some students have presented work at national society and divisional meetings. Twenty-two participants have reported entering graduate school (mostly in physics or astronomy, but also computer science, engineering, and earth sciences).

BROADER IMPACTS

In building our cohort each year, we strive to recruit a diverse population from across the US and from a wide range of institutions. In 2019-2021 our students came from a community college, small liberal arts colleges, large but not research-focused schools, as well as from schools with a high research productivity. Bringing these students here to live and perform research together helps to break down societal barriers and aid career mobility particularly for those whose schools provide limited diversity and/or research opportunities. Demographically, 55% of external participants during this period were women and 19% were from under-represented racial minorities.

While many of our participants have continued to graduate school in physics and astronomy, even if they do not, they are receiving valuable experience in critical thinking, research skills and tools, ethics, etc. Some of our participants have taken these skills into graduate school in other fields.  Others have taken them into industry with engineers and data-analysts being especially well-represented among our former participants. Several past participants, including one from the 2019 cohort, have become K-12 teachers, and others have worked in other aspects of scientific education and public outreach.

Each summer, we hosted an Astronomy Night for students from all the summer programs at LSU and as a general public outreach. The activities ideally started with a public lecture on an astronomy-related topic, followed by the participants putting on physics demonstrations and making liquid nitrogen ice cream. After sunset, the students were able to view the Moon and planets through the 11.5" Clark telescope in the Landolt Observatory. Due to pandemic restrictions, our activities and attendance were limited in 2020 or 2021, but the talk was offered online to a larger audience.
